I’m going to answer this question with an experience from the past. Although the scenario and time frame are slightly different. August 14, 2003, the power went out, everywhere.... for 3 days. Everywhere being the majority of southern Ontario northern New York. What a 3 days to be alive! The majority of stores were closed, when the sun went down, it got real dark lol. The one thing I remember most, everyone was outside. It was a different world, for 3 days. People were on their porches with battery powered radios, candles. All the kids were out and about. We all wondered for how long we would go without power. I was a young teenager, so I am unaware of the economic impact it had, or the struggles of adult life with no power (ie: getting to work, is work even open, the food in the fridge etc). Back then we didn’t have smartphones or Facebook, online shopping wasn’t a huge thing yet.. but we did have our devices like the Sony ps1 and n64, we did have internet and stuff like instant messenger. Our use of these devices/services also wasn’t likely as heavy as it is today.. however, a few hours into the black out I heard no kid complaining lol. As an adult now, I could imagine it would have been much more bothersome for those with responsibilities. I think if the internet stopped working for a year, the world would become a better place.. we are so connected now, I foresee a greater appreciation and sense of community if this were to happen.

This is a thought experiment that some have attempted to tackle in lectures and long diatribes on blogs and vlogs. It encompasses so many aspects of human existence that I cannot describe it without the best quote I have heard of it so far. Imagining today minus the Net is as content-free an exercise as imagining London in the 1840s with no steam power, New York in the 1930s with no elevators, or L.A. in the 1970s with no cars. After a while, the trellis so shapes the vine that you can’t separate the two. Blake Snow, The Atlantic In his blog, he takes on the rather long and tedious task of not only life before the internet, but life unplugged after the internet. The considerations are economic, social, interpersonal, metaphysical, and global in their impact and importance. In considering the difference, it is easy to say it would be like the 1970s or ’80s before the internet hit the mainstream market. But that is not true. To suggest that would be to suggest that removing a kidney would be like never having one in the first place. The two are not synonymous. If you have a thing, you are used to a thing. To have it removed it to experience the loss of the thing and the changes in life that come after. To have never had it is living a life without missing that which you have never known. So, I am going to stop here before I go any deeper down this rabbit hole. I encourage you to look up topics and papers and videos online about life unplugged from the internet or life without the internet or loss of the internet. The information you will find is astounding and you will not find a better answer here than you will in the wild.
